Justification: To visually inspect the ear canal and tympanic membrane for signs of infection or fluid, which could indicate otitis media.
To assess for signs of infection, such as elevated white blood cell count, which can help differentiate between bacterial and viral infections.
To evaluate the level of inflammation in the body, which can help in assessing the severity of the infection.
To assess the function of the middle ear and confirm the presence of fluid behind the eardrum, which is indicative of otitis media with effusion.
To identify any viral pathogens that may be causing the upper respiratory symptoms and contributing to the fever.
